Award.AwardTitle: Aboveground and belowground enemies and the invasion success of plants: experimental tests in the US and China
Award.AbstractNarration:
Traditional approaches to studying plant invasions have produced limited insights into the mechanisms underlying successful and widespread invasions. A wealth of reviews has indicated a need for biogeographically explicit experiments that consider a variety of biotic interactions, that include multiple populations of the invasive plant from its native and introduced range, and that utilize multiple plant species from each range to provide appropriate ecological context. This project will build on ongoing studies of the Chinese tallow tree, a species that is highly invasive in the southeast U.S., by simultaneously manipulating multiple biotic interactions in both invasive and native portions of the species' current geographic range. Field and greenhouse experiments in the US and China will be used to investigate the roles of aboveground (specialist and generalist herbivores, foliar fungi) and belowground (pathogenic fungi, mycorrhizae, herbivores) interactions in determining tallow tree success. The intellectual merit of this project is that it will enhance understanding of mechanisms that contribute to the success, or failure, of introduced species, and the relative importance of those mechanisms in native and new portions of the geographic range of an invasive species.
The substantial and growing economic impact of invasive species contributes to the broader impact of this project; better understanding of mechanisms that contribute to the success of invasive species will help guide land and resource managers. Other broader impacts include training of graduate and undergraduate students, and a significant international collaboration with scientists at four Chinese institutions.
This award is funded in part by the Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the role of interactions with aboveground (foliar fungi, herbivorous insects, extrafloral nectar tending ants) and belowground (soil pathogens, mycorrhizae, nematodes, herbivorous insects) organisms on the traits, performance, and invasion success of exotic plants, especially Chinese tallow tree (Triadica sebifera). We employed replicate common gardens and manipulative experiments in China and USA using T. sebifera from populations throughout the introduced and native ranges along with additional plant species native to the USA or China.  We found, in general,  that tallow trees from populations in the invasive (USA) range had lower levels of anti-herbivore defenses (Huang et al. 2010; Carrillo et al. 2012a; Carrillo et al. 2012b; Wang et al. 2012; Huang et al. 2013; Wang et al. 2013; Carrillo et al. 2014; Gu et al. 2014; Huang et al. 2014; Huang et al. 2015; Li et al. 2016), higher tolerance of herbivore damage (Huang et al. 2010; Wang et al. 2011; Carrillo and Siemann 2016), broader environmental tolerances (Chen et al. 2013; Yang et al. 2015b; Yang et al. 2015a; Wang et al. 2016), greater phenotypic plasticity (Zou et al. 2009; Chen et al. 2013), higher rates of mycorrhizal association (Yang et al. 2013; Yang et al. 2015b; Yang et al. 2015c), and higher growth rates than those from populations in the native range (Huang et al. 2010; Wang et al. 2011). These differences are consistent with adaptive responses to herbivore release and a greater importance of aboveground competition in the introduced range. However, plants varied in their primary and secondary metabolic responses to different types of herbivores such as aboveground vs. belowground herbivores (Huang et al. 2012; Huang et al. 2013; Huang et al. 2014; Huang et al. 2015) , specialist vs. generalist herbivores or chewing vs. sucking herbivores (Huang et al. 2014). Moreover, variation in plant traits can have cascading effects on ecosystem processes such as soil respiration and litter decomposition (Huang et al. 2013; Zhang et al. 2013; Zhang et al. 2014; Liu et al. 2015; Lu et al. 2015; Deng et al. 2016; Zhang et al. 2016).

Dozens of undergraduates were involved in this research project in the USA and China. This research project contributed to the training of three graduate students in the USA and several more in China. Numerous scientific exchanges between USA and China were catalyzed by this research collaboration. Research results were presented in class lectures, as posters and talks at national and national scientific meetings, and in presentations to the general public.
